In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific (Key Indicators) is a flagship publication of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB). This data dissemination vehicle has been refurbished 
several times in recent years. Since 2001, Key Indicators has featured a theme chapter on a 
topic of current policy interest. To reach out to a wider audience, Key Indicators has been made 
available on ADB’s website and has been formally launched since 2001 with the support of ADB 
Department of External Relations (DER). In a major overhaul in 2008, Key Indicators began to 
include data on Australia, Japan, and New Zealand; new indicators for transport, governance, 
and other sectors; and statistical commentaries on thematic areas of socioeconomic statistics 
and the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). Moreover, the Key Indicators team continues 
to strive to improve the content and quality of the publication. The technical assistance (TA) for 
the preparation and publication of Key Indicators 2011 is an ADB corporate priority. The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1  
II.  ISSUES 
2.  A number of development challenges face Asia and the Pacific. Many people are no 
longer poor, but the challenge of poverty reduction and inclusive growth still remains. The global 
crisis showed how vulnerable the region is to external shocks. Key Indicators, with its accurate 
and updated data on ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs) and its research on public 
policy issues, helps measure and track progress in attaining inclusive growth and reducing 
poverty in Asia and the Pacific, and provides a statistical basis for evidence-based policy 
making.   
 
3.  Key Indicators is ADB’s preeminent statistical data book. For over 4 decades, policy 
makers, investors, and researchers have relied on its economic, demographic, social, financial, 
and environmental statistics, updated yearly, on ADB member countries, including statistics on 
the MDG indicators. Per DER statistics, Key Indicators 2010 was the most downloaded ADB 
publication between 20 August and 31 December 2010 after its launch on 19 August 2010.    
 
4.  A special chapter, based on original research, examines a key policy or measurement 
issue, or a development challenge. “The Rise of Asia’s Middle Class” in Key Indicators 2010 
looked into the growth and impact of the rapidly expanding middle class, and the economic and 
policy implications. For Key Indicators 2011, the creation of better employment in the region is 
the chosen topic.2 The special chapter will broadly discuss employment policies that can reduce 
poverty and lead to more stable and inclusive growth in the region. Issues in the public and 
private sectors, including the role of labor market institutions, will be addressed. 
 
5.  Through rigorous econometric methods that use survey data and aggregate country data, 
as well as in-depth country studies, the special chapter will seek to identify major constraints on 
the creation of better job opportunities in Asia. Background research papers on the topic will be 
commissioned. Among other things, they will explore the impact of rural–urban migration, better 
job opportunities in the rural and informal sectors, the role of manufacturing and services in 
improving job opportunities in the urban areas, and policies and constraints in different countries. 
                                                
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 10 February 2011. 
2  The choice was prompted by the strong interest shown by the public in the creation of specific types of employment 
opportunities that can contribute to economic growth and reduce poverty. While this topic has been covered in past 
publications, the economic changes over the last 5 years make it worthwhile to revisit the issues.

2 
The chapter will also use available data to link employment opportunities to education, including 
technical and vocational education. If production time permits, qualitative studies could be 
commissioned. As equality of opportunities is a large part of better employment, the studies will 
scrutinize demographic differences in opportunities, including differences based on gender. With 
this analysis and previous research, especially that done by ADB,3 Key Indicators will suggest 
ways in which policies can improve job opportunities and speed up poverty reduction and the 
attainment of inclusive growth in the region. 
 
6.  For Key Indicators to promote ADB’s credibility as a source of factual information about 
the region and contribute effectively to better-informed policies and projects, the statistics and 
the special chapter must continuously improve in content and quality. This will require rigorous 
research,  the  publication  of  carefully  verified  statistics  on  the  member  countries,  relevant 
background papers that will flesh out the special chapter, and wider and effective dissemination. 
As it has done in the past, ERD will disseminate Key Indicators 2011 in partnership with DER.      
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The  TA  will  support  rigorous,  evidence-based  research  and  the  production  of 
high-quality statistics on emerging issues that affect the socioeconomic development of the 
DMCs.  This  information  will  shape  policies,  investment  decisions,  and  project  formulation, 
resulting  in  better-informed  policies  and  projects.  Key  Indicators  2011  will  advance  ADB’s 
reputation as an authoritative source of knowledge about the region. Appendix 2 outlines the 
planned contents of Key Indicators 2011. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The main output of the TA for Key Indicators 2011 will consist of (i) the main book, 
including the MDG and regional tables pertaining to the DMCs and the special chapter; (ii) the 
special chapter, a stand-alone publication; (iii) highlights; (iv) online links to statistical tables and 
the special chapter; and (v) background research papers. 
 
9.  The  TA  will  support  the  following  activities:  (i) reviewing  indicators  and  preparing 
questionnaires; (ii) collecting data from the member countries and from international sources; 
(iii) validating the data; (iv) preparing country, regional, and MDG tables; (v) preparing statistical 
commentaries; (vi) uploading the Key Indicators content on the web; (vii) updating data in the 
statistical database system (SDBS); (viii) holding one or more consultative workshops for the 
special chapter; (ix) doing research and preparing background papers on various topics for the 
special chapter (see para. 5 above); (x) drafting the special chapter; (xi) reviewing and editing 
the publication; (xii) preparing and laying out materials for publication; and (xiii) disseminating 
the publication. The TA will also support the preliminary activities for Key Indicators 2012 such 
as background research and workshops on themes of current policy interest; data review, 
search, and preparation; and research on statistical practices and methods.

10.  The  Key  Indicators  workshops  and  seminars  will  firm  up  the  initial  findings  in  the 
background research papers, identify constraints, and discuss the general directions of the 
special chapter. They will therefore be central to the development of the chapter. Distinguished 
panelists will be invited to the workshops.  
 
11.  Accuracy, coherence, and a consistent approach throughout the publication, as well as 
conformity to ADB style and usage guidelines, will require high-quality editing services. National 
and international consultants working closely with the Key Indicators team in the Development 
Indicators  and  Policy  Research  Division  (ERDI)  will  serve  as  economic,  manuscript,  and 
copyeditors. 
 
12.  The  dissemination  activities,  which  will  include  seminars  and  workshops  within  and 
outside ADB, will be carried out in collaboration with DER. These activities will widen the reach 
of Key Indicators and make the publication more readily useful and effective. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $800,000. The TA will be financed with a grant 
from ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 3.  
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will be the executing agency of the TA, which will be implemented by ERDI from 
February 2011 to June 2012.  
 
15.    The production of country tables and the MDG and regional tables in Key Indicators 
2011  will  require  6.0  person-months  of  international  and  54  person-months  of  national 
consulting services. The international consultants will provide overall support and prepare the 
statistical commentaries for the MDG and various themes for the regional tables, in close 
coordination with the ERDI international staff in charge of the publication project. The national 
consultants will assist in data collection from nearly 130 statistical agencies in 48 member 
countries  and  from  various  international  data  sources;  check  the  data  for  completeness, 
accuracy, and consistency and validate the data, seek clarification from data sources; prepare 
the country tables; prepare the regional and MDG tables; and upload the final data into the 
SDBS. The consultants will include those recruited for preliminary work, data research, and 
review of the data series presented in the country, regional and MDG tables for Key Indicators 
2012. In addition to the foregoing, national consultants will provide manuscript editing and 
copyediting  services  (1 person-month),  and  lay  out  the  text  and  statistical  tables 
(1 person-month).  
 
16.  The special chapter will require international consulting services for the background 
reports and original research (7.5 person-months), for manuscript editing under the authors’ 
direction  (1.5  person-months),  and  for  background  research  on  likely  themes  for  the  Key 
Indicators 2012 special chapter (5 person-months). National consultants (20 person-months) will 
provide specific insights, carry out research on a few selected countries, and assist in data

background research for the Key Indicators 2012 special chapter will need the services of 
national consultants as well (10 person-months). For Key Indicators 2011, resource persons 
with knowledge of the theme of the special chapter may also be hired from ADB member

4 
governments and local or international organizations to act as discussants during the  Key 
Indicators workshops.  
 
17.  The terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 4. Individual consultants will be 
hired, according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). Disbursements under the TA will conform to ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
18.  The major results of Key Indicators 2011 will be released to the media, policy makers, 
researchers, member countries, and other data users. The publication will be featured on ADB’s 
website. Updated data can be viewed and downloaded from the SDBS. Printed copies (with 
accompanying CD-ROMs) will be distributed worldwide. ERD will coordinate the dissemination 
in partnership with DER to capture broader and more useful client feedback. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2011, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consultants for the Statistical Tables and the Special Chapter 
 
1.  Key Economic and Statistical Indicators Expert (international, 3.5 person-
months) 
 
1.  The consultant must have worked for at least 10 years in the field of official statistics at 
the national and international levels and possess strong background and understanding of the 
concepts and methods of  compilation of socioeconomic indicators including the Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs) and possess sufficient knowledge of international data sources. In 
particular, the consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  assist the Key Indicators 2011 coordinator(s) in the overall technical management of 
the collection, compilation, review, scrutiny, validation, and approval of data in the 
country, regional, and MDG tables included in Key Indicators 2011;  
(ii)  provide technical advice and clarifications to national consultants and other country 
specialists on data compilation from country and international sources, and suggest 
best alternative sources when data are not available from targeted sources; and 
(iii)  ensure that all the processes of data collection and compilation and the production of 
tables are carried out according to the Key Indicators 2011 production timetable and 
schedule and meet the highest quality standards.  
 
2.  Economic Statistics Expert 1 (international, 1.5 person-months, intermittent) 
 
2.  The consultant must have a strong background in economics or statistics, be highly 
proficient in written English, and have extensive practical knowledge of the production of official 
statistics in Asia and the Pacific. In particular, the consultant will: 
 
(i)  review tables in parts II and III of Key Indicators 2011 to suggest new indicators and 
other feasible changes; 
(ii)  draft according to the Handbook of Style and Usage of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) thematic statistical commentaries covering the seven themes and eight MDGs, 
analyze key trends, and incorporate new developments in the thematic areas;  
(iii)  ensure that the indicators commented on and the ideas presented are consistent 
with  those  in  other  ADB  publications  and  are  different  from  the  corresponding 
commentaries in Key Indicators 2010 to avoid repetitions; 
(iv)  discuss the draft commentaries and related issues with the Development Indicators 
and Policy Research Division (ERDI) staff concerned; 
(v)  prepare highlights for the MDG and regional tables as part of the overall highlights 
for Key Indicators 2011, discuss accordingly with the ERDI staff concerned; 
(vi)  assist  in  preparing  the  key  messages  and  review  the  press  release  for  Key 
Indicators 2011; and 
(vii)  perform other related tasks assigned by ERDI. 
 
3.  Economic Statistics Expert 2 (international, 1.0 person-months, intermittent) 
 
3.  The consultant must possess a strong background in economics or official statistics and 
understanding of the concepts of wide variety of socioeconomic indicators including the MDGs. 
He or she must have at least 10 years of national and international work experience in official 
statistics. In general, the consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  review the indicators presented in the country, regional, and MDG tables; 
(ii)  suggest changes that could be incorporated (additional indicators to be considered 
for inclusion, less relevant indicators to exclusion, changes in data structures in the 
tables, changes in the data themes in regional tables);  
(iii)  suggest methods of aggregation for regional indicators; and

(iv)  suggest ways of presenting the statistical commentaries. 
 
4.  Lead  Labor  Economics  Consultant  (international,  1.5  person-months 
intermittent) 
 
4.  The consultant should have a strong background in development or labor economics 
and extensive work experience in employment issues using rigorous quantitative methods. 
Familiarity with the empirical literature on economic growth and employment is necessary. 
Tasks are as follows: 
 
 (i)  document  policies  and  interventions  that  enable  individuals  to  enter  good 
employment  and  distinguish  between  those  aimed  at  getting  people  into  good 
employment  and  those  for  creating  and  fostering  good  employment  at 
microeconomic and macroeconomic levels using experiences from developing Asia 
(and beyond); 
(ii)  use data from selected developing member countries (DMCs) to identify impact of 
select interventions or policies on employment and the creation of employment; and  
 (iii)  advise on direction of research for special chapter and take the lead in drafting the 
special chapter. These tasks will require the consultant to do the following: 
(a)    review  draft  outline  of  special  chapter  prepared  by  ADB  staff  and  provide 
comments and suggestions for its finalization; 
(b)    review draft terms of reference for background papers prepared by ADB staff 
and provide comments and suggestions for their finalization;  
(c)    review and comment on draft background papers;  
(d)    attend May 2011 workshop and provide comments and suggestions for the 
finalization of background papers; 
(e)    provide advice to the authors of the background papers as required; 
(f)    draft a paper that will serve as the basis for the introduction to the special 
chapter to be presented at the May 2011 workshop; and 
(g)   draft  a  paper  to  serve  as  basis  for  the  entire  special  chapter  of  Key 
Indicators 2011, that compiles all of the original research associated with the 
special chapter and brings out the key policy messages and findings.  
 
5.  International  Economics/Sociological  Consultants (international, 1 person-
month each, intermittent; 3 consultants) 
 
5.  Consultants should have expertise related to labor markets, employment, or good job 
growth. They should have skills to analyze issues and prescribe policies related to this area on 
the  basis  of  the  most  up-to-date  rigorous  research  methods.  The  tasks  assigned  to  the 
international consultants are as follows: 
 
(i)  develop major policy prescriptions important in creation of good employment and 
movement of people into good jobs for a specific focus area on the basis of rigorous 
research methods;  
(ii)  synthesize the findings in a report; 
(iii)  provide  input  to  Economics  and  Research  Department  (ERD)  staff  and  lead 
consultant regarding policies and interventions relevant to good employment creation 
that can be used to evaluate the impact of selected policies and interventions; and 
(iv)  present the papers at the May 2011 workshop in Manila. 
 
6.  Survey Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
 
6.  The international consultant must have previous work experience in survey  design, 
sampling, and rollout of survey activities. Understanding the links between questions and policy 
analysis using rigorous methods is necessary. The survey specialist will do the following tasks: 
 
(i)  provide advice on where sampling should occur, given cost–benefit trade-offs;

9.  Manuscript/Copyeditor (national, 1 person-month, intermittent) 
 
9.  In close coordination with the Key Indicators coordinator, the manuscript/copyeditor shall 
be responsible for the manuscript editing and copyediting of parts II, III, and IV of the Key 
Indicators  2011  publication,  including  its  tables  and  charts.  In  particular,  the 
manuscript/copyeditor will carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  reorganize text according to the ADB’s Handbook of Style and Usage so that the 
subject matter is easy to understand and is logically presented;  
(ii)  query discrepancies, possible typographic errors, non-English terms, obvious errors 
in mathematical calculations, questionable proper names, bibliographic references, 
and the like, but excluding fact checking; 
(iii)  edit the foreword and acknowledgments, reference lists, and tables and figures, and 
recast these if required; 
(iv)  ensure  consistency  of  subheads  and  references  to  tables,  figures,  appendixes, 
footnotes, and other parts of the text; 
(v)  check final changes; and sign off on the layout.  
 
10.  Graphic Designer (national, 1 person-month, intermittent) 
 
10.  The graphic designer will be responsible for text layout, encoding of corrections, re-
layout, and formatting of graphic elements of Key Indicators 2011, including the refining of its 
web version. This consultant must be adept at working with Creative Suite 4 (or 5), Microsoft 
Word, and Microsoft Excel. He or she will prepare InDesign, Illustrator, and PDF files of the 
interiors and covers using original manuscripts submitted in Microsoft Word and Microsoft Excel. 
In particular, the graphic designer will: 
 
(i)  prepare the initial and final layout of Key Indicators 2011; 
(ii)  reformat and encode corrections in the main text, tables, and charts of Key Indicators 
2011 according to the comments received from ERDI staff and consultants ; 
(iii)  deliver the final artwork of Key Indicators 2011 covers to ERDI for final offset printing; 
(iv)  deliver the web-ready and pre-flighted1 consolidated PDF files of the publication to 
ERDI; and  
(v)  perform other related tasks assigned by ERDI.  
 
11.  Labor  Economists  for  the  Country  Case  Studies  (4  DMCs)  (national, 
2 person-months each, intermittent; 4 consultants) 
 
11.  The  national  consultants  should  have  well-rounded  knowledge  of  policies  in  their 
countries and their effects on employment, job quality, poverty, and upward mobility. They 
should be knowledgeable on nationally representative labor force survey data sets on wages, 
earnings, and job employment and have access to these. The tasks assigned are as follows: 
 
(i)  describe major policies and interventions that benefit the creation of good jobs and 
the movement of people into good jobs in their country; 
(ii)  identify common beliefs that may exist regarding populations that are not in good 
jobs and seem unable or incapable of gaining access to these good jobs;  
(iii)  identify specific policies and interventions that can be evaluated using labor force 
survey data possibly in combination with other data sources such as household 
income and expenditure surveys or firm-level data;  
(iv)  synthesize the findings in reports; 
(v)  provide input to ERD staff and the international consultant regarding policies and 
interventions relevant to good job and employment creation that can be used to

(vi)  present the country papers at the May 2011 workshop in Manila. 
 
12.  Survey  Data  Processor  and  Labor  and  Employment  Analysts (national, 
6 person-months each, 2 consultants) 
 
12.  The  national  consultant  must  have  previous  work  experience  with  database 
management (especially with large-scale household survey data), processing, and encoding 
and strong background in the statistical and econometric analysis of labor-related issues using 
labor force and firm-level survey data. He or she should have worked with the data analysis and 
statistical software STATA or SAS. The tasks assigned are as follows: 
 
(i)  clean new data procured, analyze data limitations, create new variables; 
(ii)  prepare technical documentation of all cleaning of data, creation of new variables; 
and limitations to data, as well as a codebook;   
(iii)  develop potential indicators for the survey;  
(iv)  describe  and  compare  different  approaches  by  researchers  and  international 
organizations to forecast cross-country job and employment rates based on different 
scenarios for the evolution of economic growth and distributional changes;  
(v)  make a recommendation on the approach to use on the basis of various criteria 
including usefulness for policy purposes, feasibility, and computational ease; and 
(vi)  set  up  user-friendly  database  for  executing  and  evaluating  employment  trends 
according to recommended approach (as discussed and agreed on with ERD staff).   
 
 
B.  Consultants for the Preparatory  Activities for the  Key Indicators 2012 Special 
Chapter  
 
1.   Economics Consultants (international, 5 person-months) 
 
13.  The consultants should have excellent working experience in general development or 
urban economics and a good knowledge of DMC economies. Under the direct supervision of the 
relevant ERDI staff, the consultants will: 
 
 
 (i)   prepare essays on development issues and country reports as may be assigned;  
and  
(ii)   perform  all  other  functions  and  responsibilities  assigned  by  the  assistant  chief 
economist of ERDI. 
 
2.   Economics Consultants (national, 10 person-months) 
 
14.  The consultants should have excellent working experience in general economics. Under 
the direct supervision of the ERDI staff concerned, the consultants will assist in the economic 
research  work  of  the  ERD  and  undertake  general  economic  research.  In  particular,  the 
consultants will: 
 
(i)   conduct research on issues related to economic development, growth, trade and 
investment, human capital development, employment, and urbanization in Asia and 
the Pacific;  
(ii)   support the country economic analyses;  
(iii)  contribute to the preparation of the Key Indicators; and 
(iv)  undertake ad hoc research and other assignments assigned by the assistant chief 
economist of ERDI.
